climbs.name: La Loutre
climbs.fa: Claude Bérubé 1 Régis Richard with help of Jacques Lemay, Jan 13-14 1977

content.description:
P1

P2

P3

P4 WI4. Ice, up to the base of a more vertical wall of ice.

P5 WI4/4+. Continue in direction of the final pillar, which should start looking quite impressive now.

P6 WI5+ 60m. the final pilar, and approximativement 50m of pure vertical ice.

 Rappel in the route. Abalakovs, rock horns and some old fixed pieces of slings and ropes should take you down safely. Don't hesitate to replace suspicious gear. Rapping pitch 2 is a bit tricky (the snow slope). The best way is to walk backward the snow slope with tension in the rappel, and then clip a little tree as a redirection 5m before getting to the last rappel anchor. Falling during this sideway rappel and going for a swing might be tragic.



You can see the final pilar most of the approach. The fist part of the approach is shared with the Pomme d'Or trail, but continue on the left. Pretty steep snow slope. 

Trad rack for a full pitch of mixed climbing, ice rack for 60m long ice pitches.

content.description:
The line on the left of La Pomme d'Or. Absolutely classic, probably the best alpine route in Québec of relatively moderate level. This variation starts on Cascade 74 (first 3 pitches) then moves to La loutre.

P1 M4. Ramp going up to a tree.

P2. Snow ramp going to the base of a rocky couloir which is the P3. Barely no protection for the entire 55m of snow. Don't fall there

P3 M5. The mixed climbing crux pitch, may feel harder depending the conditions. Very nice alpine feeling, this is one of the really beautiful pitches of the route.

P4 WI4. Ice, up to the base of a more vertical wall of ice.

P5 WI4/4+. Continue in direction of the final pillar, which should start looking quite impressive now.

P6 WI5+ 60m. the final pilar, and approximativement 50m of pure vertical ice.

Rappel in the route. Abalakovs, rock horns and some old fixed pieces of slings and ropes should take you down safely. Don't hesitate to replace suspicious gear. Rapping pitch 2 is a bit tricky (the snow slope). The best way is to walk backward the snow slope with tension in the rappel, and then clip a little tree as a redirection 5m before getting to the last rappel anchor. Falling during this sideway rappel and going for a swing might be tragic.


You can see the final pilar most of the approach. The fist part of the approach is shared with the Pomme d'Or trail, but continue on the left. Pretty steep snow slope.
Trad rack for a full pitch of mixed climbing, ice rack for 60m long ice pitches.

La Pomme D'or is THE classic long ice route in La Malbaie, Quebec. Many climbers have cut their teeth on this beautiful climb. From multi day adventures to day long solos, this climb gets traffic and deserving so. This climb is a classic in every sense of the word. The route can range from 5 to 6+ depending on your line of attack. The opening pitches are in the easy 4 range until about 1/3 the way up. Then things get steeper. On the upper 1/3 you can choose to move either right or left and select from vertical pillars to lower angle ice In my experience the far left was easiest with the right being harder. P1 M3 PG/R 30m. First pitch below the headwall you go up on the right slab slinging bushes and sketchy rock pro. You can setup a belay here or start traversing left on the ramp but you also may want to simu-climb to avoid the drag to the next anchor. P2 M3 PG/R 40m. Traverse left using rock pro and depending on the conditions you may end up placing stubbies in the ice. Anchor off of pitons at the end of the traverse, 5m right of the ice corner which marks the start of the ice climb. P3 WI5 PG 50-60m. First 10m you may only get 10cm screws in though there’s some rock pro on the right. P4 WI5 50-60m. P5-6 WI5-6 50-60m. The second to last pitch is often the crux, a direct approach can get you into some WI6+ territory. As of winter 2010-2011, you can drive past the outer gates and into the park itself on minimally maintained road to the inner gate. This shortens the approach significantly (31km vs 3.5km). You will pass many climbs in route but La Pomme will be noticeable off in the distance on your left.
On the river below the climb you can look up to scout your approach up the talus, and snowfield. There are alternative starts but the main route goes up a tight corner at the top of couloir that cannot really be seen from below.

If camping, You'll need to pay the fee and can only camp in designated spots like across the river on the road side there is a small designated camping site with a picnic table as well. The route goes with screws alone. Bring enough to build all your anchors off of screws as well as protect each pitch. Later in the season you will usually find a nice line of V-threads leading the way down. Trust them at your own risk!

A spectacular route on the right side of the La Pomme d'Or wall!  Approach is the same as for La Pomme, just continue up the snow gully for another 75-100m.  Warning: This gully acts as a funnel for any ice dropped by climbers already on La Pomme or La Ruee.  Description is based on February, 2020 conditions.

P1, WI3: Climb easy ice to a short headwall below a free-standing pillar.

P2, WI5+: Climb up to the pillar and then enjoy 30m of steep, sustained climbing!

P3 and 4, WI4: Fun climbing to the base of a rock wall, with an overhang about 30m up

P5, M7: Mixed climbing clipping bolts to the right, leads to an ice overhang, which is burly but doesn't last long.  Continue up interesting, blocky, mixed climbing to a nice ledge with a bolted anchor.

P6, WI5+; Traverse left 10m, then climb a huge, steep, sustained, curtain/pillar to the top.

Rappel the route.

This is as good a mixed route as you'll find anywhere, do it!



Approach as for La Pomme d'Or, La Ruee lies further up the snow gully to the right.

Bollts, medium to large stoppers, Camalots .5 - 3, doubles up to #2
